I feel sorry for your poor flask. You heated a kilo of solid MgSO4 (based on anydrous weight) using an electromantle (and not even one of the right size.) It must have been over 400C at the bottom, cooling to 100C at the top. The heat transfer would have been abysmal. You could have done like 500g of hydrate (250g MgSO4 + 250g water) and saved a load of trouble, and also considered an apparatus with better heat transfer (glass with oil bath / woods metal bath / best of all a sand bath or even a metallic still such as a pressure cooker.) But I guess then the video would be less dramatic.

What you have left at the end of the process is a pretty good desiccant that can be used to absorb moisture in areas that you want to keep dry.

It is easier to evaporate the water out of the original H2O saturated material through the use of a microwave process.
The temperature of the material can get quite high in the microwave, and it's a safety consideration that has to be acknowledged if such should be attempted.

In the mining engineering area, the use of " autogenous grinders" which tumble large rocks of the material to be ground against itself, is effective, and reduces wear on the steel or other material which otherwise would be used to do the grinding.
I don't think that lapidary tumblers would be big enough to do the job, but they do model what would work!

Another way to do your experiment is to weigh an amount of Epsom salt, (.7 H2O) put it in Vision ware or similar vessel, and microwave until the water is vibrated away, (keeping the temperatures attained from melting the micro..), and then re-weighing the now-consolidated chunk to see what weight has left.

I know both where the other expected water went and why the water tasted acidic when you drank a little of it. One of the chemical products has to H2SO4 when it combines with liquid water, even if that liquid water originate from its own original chemical form when it's sold. This is something that greatly alarmed me when I realized that I had been taking relaxing Epsom salt baths every weekend to help me be a better student during the week (also also during the weekend because I obviously also had to study). Shouldn't that have meant that I was actually bathing in a bath of sulfuric acid! I reasoned that it must have been okay because it had to be really dilute and that made me wonder why it should be relaxing to take a bath in any concentration of sulfuric acid!

Therefore, some of the water probably is hard to separate because, once it forms a liquid sulfuric acid, it's going to be harder to get the water molecule out of that (which is what you also surmised). Now, having to take lots of chemistry and physics, even though my major was biology, I obviously had to take even more biology classes and one of them was neurobiology, which included things like how we taste things. What tells our brain that something tastes sour is nothing more than a receptor (in the neuron sense, as opposed to a self surface receptor protein) that detects an excessive concentration of H+ ions so it's just an acid receptor. So if there was probably a little sulfuric acid left in that water. I wonder if reverse osmosis would have gotten it out. Anyway, great video!

So I added it into my coffee and the sugar container. I didn’t notice it tasted different because I had Covid at the time couldn’t taste anything.
Needless to say, I took a lot of dumps that day.

EDIT: for everyone asking me why I was putting sugar in my coffee when I couldn’t taste it, it’s called “force of habit”.

Pro tip: if you need to bust up something like that, grab a tarp and a bucket. Poke a hole in the tarp and feed the handle of a sledgehammer (or whatever you have) through. Put your material in the bucket, and then put your sledgehammer in there. You can then either bungee the tarp around the bucket, or freeball it and just let it hang loose. Then just start smashing it like churning butter. The tarp will keep chips from flying around everywhere, and if you use a decently strong bucket or one that lies completely flush with the floor, then you can get most of the strength of the concrete under it to smash against.

You can also put something in the bottom of the bucket if you want a strong surface to pound against, too. Something like a piece of sheet metal, or an old 10-20 pound (metal) weight works well. I suppose you could also just pour some concrete into the bottom and let it dry, too, but then you run the risk of contaminating your material with chunks of concrete. Plus, you are in a situation where you need a solution like this, then you probably aren't in the market for a solution that requires that kind of prep time...

You can also just wrap it up in a tarp and smash it that way, but the likelihood of puncturing the tarp are much higher than with the bucket. This only works for the softer side of rocky materials, but it is a quick and dirty way to get it done that works better than you might think.

Fun fact - Epsom salt is an ore of magnesium .

FYI there is actually more water trapped under the crust of our planet, in the mantle layer, than can be found above the crust, as in, all of the water and ice/snow in all of the oceans, lakes, glaciers, etc. Some estimates put it at anywhere from about 1-3x more water under/in our planet than on the planet. It has a huge impact on plate tectonics and also affects volcanic activity. A large amount of the water is in the transition zone in between the upper and lower mantle layers but there is also a great deal of water inside the rocks and minerals which make up the mantle zones. About 7 or 8 years ago some diamonds were found which contained the mineral ringwoodite and ringwoodite itself contains 1.5% water by weight. Further, the diamonds were found within kimberlite (which had obviously been brought to the surface by volcanic eruption), the deepest kind of volcanic rocks.

So technically you are correct in your assumption that the epsom salt obtained water from its environment but I’m guessing you had some other geological process in mind? I’ve actually no idea if the water I’m referring to has anything whatsoever to do with water inside epsom salt but just thought I’d share this with you.

I used to make Epson salt for a living from base chemicals. The water is indeed from the manufacturering process. It's made in giant digester tanks by combining magnesium, sulfuric acid, and a LOT of water. The resulting slurry is then filtered through a chemical press to get rid of impurities. After that it's flash cooled to trap the water in a crystallization process.
After that process its dried and sorted by crystal size for various applications.

This reminds me of chalcanthite (a blue crystal), one of my favourite chemicals (also known as blue vitriol, or copper (II) sulphate pentahydrate). Anhydrous copper suphate is a white powder - and heating copper sulphate (pentahydrate) will cause water to slowly break off and condense until it forms the anhydrous powder. Though it's important to be wary with it, as if it continues to be heated, it will decompose and sulphuric acid can be released in a gaseous state. And yet, condensing the acid and dissolving in water, you can grow the crystals.

This reminds me of subduction zone volcanism. The increasing heat forces the subducting slab to release huge amounts of fluids that used to be bound to oceanic crust minerals, I guess similarly to how water bound in epsom salt. Water in these fluids drops the melting point of the overlying astenosphere to the point where magma is generated. The magma is less viscous than the surrounding continental crust, and it contains lots of gases. This makes it mobile and buoyant, so it rises to the surface of the crust where it extrudes as lava.

Huh... that does raise an interesting philosophical question...

Is that really old water, pulled from the environment by whatever natural process formed the epsom salt?

Is it brand new water, created when you pulled it out of crystalline form?

Or do we have to say that it is truly ancient water that evaporated out of rocks sometime during the Late Heavy Bombardment and/or was deposited by comets?

Or is it perhaps older, still, its constituent parts created some twelve or thirteen billion years ago in the supernovae at the end of some Population II and III stars' lives?

When did it become "water"? When the oxygen was created? When it bound to the hydrogen? But surely those hydrogen atoms have been exchanged trillions of times over the eons, so... when it crystallized in the salts and became stabilized? When it was freed from the crystals by heating in your lab?

But I'm sure, as a chemist, you've pondered such questions many times before, no?

The timing of this is insanely serendipitous.  I've recently started using Epsom Salt as plant fertilizer and have been measuring EC/PPMs of water before and after. I'm new to this so the "heptahydrate" concerned me at first. Upon discovering it was the natural form of magnesium sulfate I decided to try it mixed into my plant water reservoir. I found its incredibly inconsistent when tested with an EC probe and it seems almost impossible to determine TDS difference in advance from measuring out granules by traditional means.  It also seems that dissolving epsom salt with luke warm water increases PPM(dissolving?) rapidly, whereas when mixing epsom salt in room temperature water, the PPM increase seems much more gradual, and may go up over time when tested again. Hydrates are really nifty. Lots of natural ones: Gypsum, Muscovite, Opal etc. Hydrates are used (and have been used since antiquity) industrially. Cement is sold as an anhydrous (or nearly anhydrous) powder and then mixed with fillers and aggregates and then water. When cement (and plaster BTW) mixed with water hardens, it isn't drying out. Rather the liquid water is being picked up by the molecules of the cement and forming a hydrate. Much like what happened when you added water to your own anhydrous (or monohydrous) powder.

To clarify water you can use Whatman 934-AH glass fiber filter paper which removes particles larger than 1.5-micron. If your chemicals won't attack cellulose, there are less expensive pap3ers. You can get Whatman 934-AH from the major scientific supply houses.

You can also consider using a "filter aid." This is a fine grained solid, like diatomaceous earth, that you mix with the suspension prior to filtering. It increases the speed and effectiveness of the filter.
http://www.generalfiltration.com/assets/uploads/Filter_Aid_Filtration.pdf

It would be interesting to see if you could clarify milk and muddy water using a coffee filter and filter aid.

Just think that the stuff we call 'soda' in the uk is really sodium carbonate, this also has water of crystallisation and is really called 'sodium carbonate decahydrate', meaning that for every molecule of sodium carbonate there are 10 molecules of water attached. This bond is not very good and if soda crystals are laid out on a dish, they will start to get a powdery surface, this is 'sodium carbonate monohydrate'. When I was a 12 year old schoolboy 64 years ago, we were looking at crystals in chemistry. I decided to make a large side crystal by growing one from soda. Epsom salt is produced one of two ways, either it is sourced from naturally occurring springs (which is the more expensive way) or it is created by dissolving magnesium carbonate (MgCO3) in sulfuric acid (H2SO4) which is the more common way. Last year, after a day-long hike, I decided to run a bath and poured in about 1/3 of the container shown in this video, into a deep bath. I jumped in, and laid back for about 40 minutes until the water started to cool. Within a few hours, I was running to the toilet constantly. Actually, after the first few times, I decided to stay in the bathroom until I had nothing left inside me, because I could barely walk - so I just sat there. In the end, I was passing clear water - which meant I was drawing on water from my muscles and organs. I was dehydrated and couldn't think straight, and I was in terrible pain. Fortunately, I called a friend who brought me a gallon of water, some electrolytes, and some anti-diarrhoea medication. I was in bed for the next 48 hours and at one point thought I was going to die.

Next time you want to cool down a glass beaker without it breaking: get yourself a ceramic insulation blanket. Turn off the heat, wrap the whole shebang in the blanket and walk away, it will take much longer to cool but you had all night anyway. These blankets are used to slowly cool down blown glass pieces (and to line the inside of kilns) to prevent the thermal stress that breaks glass when cooling. Its the temperature differential between the surface of the glass vs the interior of the glass that causes it to break. If you can cool the whole thing down evenly by insulating it you can prevent this. Bonus: you can also use the ceramic blanket to insulate the project while heating it instead of using aluminum foil. It does a much better job and is safer since the outside of the blanket will remain cooler than the foil.

Something tells me, Epsom salt would make an excellent all-purpose spaceship material. If you start out with the dehydrated bricks of it, it should make great anti-meteorite armor, while also soaking up excess humidity to become harder and more of a radiation shielding. The bricks could probably be glued together by simply moistening the edges and then quickly assembling them before they harden. Then, the hydrated form can be used as a heat shield for the reentry phase, since it can handle a good amount of heat and self-cools by releasing water. Carved shapes of it could be stacked inside the landing gear to intentionally crush, and absorb impact. Once landed, it can be used for radiation shielding again, but also for moisture control and in-situ moisture harvesting. In the event of an air leak, it should snatch humidity, liquefy, and re-harden. It could possibly be used as an emergency shelter in its hydrate-glued brick form again, but in the shape of an igloo. This time, the absorbed humidity would keep the inside warm, while it forms a hardened shell that re-heals when cracked. Furthermore, it can be turned into sulfuric acid, which is a handy chemical, but can also harvest water from air, but it is normally liquid, and therefore, easier to use in automated machinery.

Nile: With glassware, even the borosilicate stuff you're using for lab vessels, there are two things to keep in mind when heating and cooling. First, Always heat and cool SLOWLY!!! (The slower the better.) Glass gets thermally stressed when you let it heat up or cool rapidly, because it heats and cools unevenly. That causes the glass to expand and contract differently in different parts of the glass, causing the glass to eventually tear itself apart.

The second is to be conscious of the properties of the stuff you're heating and/or cooling inside, especially if it's going to harden into a lump. You always want to make sure that the stuff cooling inside the glass shrinks faster than the glass, and that the stuff on the outside shrinks slower. That is why glass molds are typically clay or plaster for stuff on the outside of the glass piece, and the molds are metal for stuff that's going to be on the inside of the glass piece.

I wanted to pose my theory for the lacking milliliters of water. Sure the container of Epsom salt you got was a container with exactly a 4 liter capacity, buut that is if it contains liquid, because liquid won't allow air to be trapped in there with it. But we're talking about Epsom salt, a crystal with various unique sizes and shapes, that plus the fact that those crystals are solid causes them to stack and butt against eachother awkwardly, which results in thousands of tiny air pockets being trapped inbetween all the crystals, thusly a 4 liter container of Epsom Salt, truly contains a little bit less than 4 liters of Epsom Salt.

Cement and bread do the same thing.  Cement hardens because the water combines with the cement to form a different chemical.  Bread left out does not dry but goes stale because the water combines with the flour and forms a different chemical.  If you want dry bread for bread crumbs or cubes you have to heat it before it goes stale to remove the water before it combines with the flour.

Nile, great video. I didnt realize this about epsom. I know what it is i just never really considered the formula long enough to put together that its is mostly water.
A few things:
1. All water is ancient. The only real way to meaningfully assign an age to water is at the molecularl level and even then its simply a matter of determinging how long that hydrogen has been vibing with those oxygen molecules, thats kinda pointless and would be impossible to really do outside of burning hydrogen in an oxygen atmosphere to produce water vapor and condensing it then saying that "this collection of water is x old relationally"
Otherwise. Most atoms are if not relative to each other pretty closs to the same age, they are so much older than us that the discussion at this broad a level is pointless. A billion years here or there isnt much to sneeze at, and all matter on earth other than perhaps a few odd out of system orignating meteorites is approximately the same age in respect to its location on the earth or in the sol system.
IE all water is about the same age since i havent seen any orbital tanker ships dropping any new water off.
2. Your set up ham strung you here.
You should have created a large sealed vessle that allowed you to heat the salt such that it had a very high surface area to volume ratio. This would have sped up the process of drying it out, and avoided the chunk issue.
Heating it up in a ball caused it to become very inefficent at absorbing heat and releasing water vapor.
It has to heat up and vent vapor the same way, from the outside inward. So basically, the heat is having to travel through the ball, but it wants to rise, and its going to do this along the surface better than it will through the center, so the ball vents heat better at the surface than it absorbs it at the cente because of the greater suraface area.
Once the center does get to temp, the outer salts will be drier than the inner salts, and as the vapor passes through some of it will get trapped. It will get released, but slowly as you saw.
Heating it up in a single wide and thin layer will avoid both of these problems.
Heres what you should use.
To to n automotive parts store and buy a large sheet of high temperature gasket material.
Go to a restraunt supply store and buy the largest chaffing dish you can get that comes with a lid that fits tightly. One that comes with its own stand is perfect.
Now plumb the lid like you did the flask. Then cut a gasket from the sheet that will fit along the lip of the chafing dish such the the lid will still fit on the pan. Fit the gasket in place and put the lid on, and using small c clamps, hold it in place.
Using a small drill bit, drill several holes through the lips of the lid and pan, all the way around. You are putting in holes for little screws to be used to seal the dish, which is the next step, install little bolts and nuts to seal the two halves together.
This will be much more efficient.
You might have to insulate this to make it more efficient and i reccomend not using direct firing to heat the pan at these temps. It will burn through it.

Nothing is a mystery here. It might sound astonishing, but industrially created magnesium sulfate is made from metallic magnesium dissolved in sulphuric acid. Mg + H2SO4 -> MgSO4·7H2O + H2. Water is taken out of the sulphuric acid solution. An slight excess of acid dissolves all metal, but traces of H2SO4 remain. That explains the bad smell (SO2) and low pH. Additionally, I suspect, they don't took 99.999% Mg for bath salt. Therefore many other sulfates with low melting points can be present in the extracted water. I use it as a low temperature* desiccant.
*It tends to slowly go from hepta to hexa above about 305K. If heated very slow in an oven and or using vacuum you can evap the H2O faster than it is released from the crystal avoiding the self dissolving issue and obtain a granular powder. The chunk form from liquid drying still acts as desiccant but is slow, so best for maintaining low moisture in a storage container. Once the chunk form as rehydrated to heptahydrate it is much weaker and easy to break up. (or just dissolve it and precipitate crystals)

Well this is probably too late to be read, but Calcum Chloride is pretty interesting.
I used CaCl6 for an ice bath, and it reached REALLY low temperatures!
In one book CaCl was listed to reach up to -55C in an ice bath!

Dry ice is a bit hard to come by in my place, and it's so expensive that I had to look for alternatives.
I had to try that out.

I got some food grade CaCl monohydrate for cheap, and added tap water to reach slightly above 6*h2o, since that was the hydration state listed.
What was interesting to see was that the (now really hot, above 70c) salt solution crashed other salts out of the tap water,
so I filtered it to get the cleanest purity possible.

I then boiled off enough water to reach a temperature that would show it's mostly the hexahydrate.
Letting it cool off and crystalize fully over night ended up with a similar situation as you, tho a beaker of CaCl6 crystal definitely looks way cooler :-).
It was impossible to break it fast enough withot it soaking moisture from the air, so I had to heat it again.
This time I poured it it onto stainless steel trays and covered them to prevent additional hydration.
The resulting thin film was easy to quickly break up and put into a bag.

I bagged the bag and bagged it again, and smashed it with a hammer into small pieces, about 3-5mm.
To make sure I'd get the best result, I put it into the freezer. Im not sure if that even does anything tbh.
To test the endothermic reaction I mixed the CaCl6 with crushed ice, at a 1:1 ratio, using a beaker.
What I ended up getting was pretty impressive, after 10 minutes of temps dropping I had a slush that reached under -31c!

Considering that you can just boil off the water again this is a pretty economic method to reach really low temps.
I'm not sure how you can reach the (theoretical?) -55c, It could be that the ratio could be better, while having the salt powdered without any adsorption of air moisture.

To get more accurate hydration, I tried baking the salt to a monohydrate, and planned to add distilled water to it to get a perfect hexahydrate.
But it turned out that this is really hard to do in a humid climate, the pure CaCl quickly pulled moisture from the air, and ruined the attempt.
If you spread some CaCl powder onto a surface you can literally watch how it hydrates.
If you put a microscope slide just above the surface of the salt, you can even see traces of the salt sticking to it!
The amount of energy released when it hydrates is so much that it makes the molecules jump! When you have it exposed to air you can definitely smell it in the near area.

The coolest thing about this salt was the crystal growth tho, I've never seen such big and clean hexagonal crystals.

Bro in case you didn't know, the "clandestine" way to do this is much easier, just throw it on a cookie tray and put it in the oven at 500F. After a few hours, it's "anhydrous", at least for the vast majority of applications.

Then, rather than collecting the distillate, just weigh the cookie tray before and after to deduce the amount of water removed.

EDIT: Just finished the video and it gave me an idea, how quickly does near-anhydrous MgSO4 re-absorb water from the air? Could this be used on planes and boats as a "deserted island" emergency kit to produce potable water? Seems like it might be easier to concentrate the water vapor given off by this than the traditional route, I.e: sea water distillation. It would also make the setup and maintenance easier, you just need three bottles and a tube, one bottle left open with MgSO4 to absorb water from the air, another bottle for the boiling MgSO4, connected with a silicon tube to the 3rd bottle, to collect the H2O. After one of the 2 MgSO4 bottles is essentially "dry", you just swap it with the other bottle that has been absorbing humidity.

This would provide a constant stream of water and all you would need for it to keep working is a fire, and to switch the tube every few hours.

EDIT2: A further refinement would see the design reduced to only need two bottles, one for boiling MgSO4 and the other to receive the vapor; The main bottle would require two tiny tesla valves, one to only let air in and one to lead out to the silicone tube. The diameter of the tesla valves' width would have to be correlated with the speed that water is released from the MgSO4 n-hydrate, to produce a mild vacuum effect.

If you've ever used magnesium sulfate as a drying agent for any reaction then it's not very hard to believe how much water is in it. before using it as a drying agent, you need to get rid of that water. Dump your magnesium sulfate into a pie dish put the oven on 400 and let the dish sit in there until the magnesium sulfate is opaque and hard. Take it out and weigh it and you'll see how much water you've lost. I've never tried to capture the water but I know when you do this and you open the oven steam pours out.

I work in ceramics and process my own materials from rocks, the easiest way to deal with this is by using a ball mill. You could load it up and turn it on and walk away. If you have to do anything like this in the future I would invest in a ball mill, you'll save yourself a lot of effort and time. The type I use has a ceramic chamber filled with extremely refractory porcelain balls (you could also use steal balls), you can process dry and will not have to add any water. If the expense of a ball mill is too costly you could also build one out of a simple electric motor, there are a lot of tutorials here on youtube for this.

A better way to use the ion-exchange resin would be to mix it with the water first, and put it on a low stir for 30 minutes or so, and then pour it over a filter of your choice, rather than do several passes. It maximizes the surface area exposure and allows time for maximum binding. Sure, you can also do extra passes if you want, but this is how we use that stuff to deionize Urea for biochemistry. It is also advice I give to newer biochemistry students when using affinity-chromatography resin generally, to use a batch system as a first pass, rather than a flow system like FPLC.

i've been to a manufacturing plant before, they make it by doing some chemistry with raw dolomite, and sulfuric acid that i've mostly forgotten about as it was 15 years ago. we were looking at the facility as a potential logistics site for a sulfur remediation project we were doing at a near by power plant as we were using the same dolomite ore. the place was literally just a beefed up version of a simple wet chem lab... making the Epsom is a wet process, that's definitely where the water came from. I can't remember the details of how it was done, but i do remember how hot and humid it was inside for a brisk February day, how the air was so acidic it would burn your nose a bit when you breathed in, and all the nasty leaky pipes with Epsom stalactites all over the shop from the crappy plumbing jobs... that particular shop was a shady place...
also, they do make lab-grade rock crushers for less than $1000 online... they're very common in coal, ore, soil and concrete labs...

Hey @NileRed, no clue if you'll ever see this, but: You broke one of the cardinal rules of thermodynamics: thermal shock. Cool it down slowly by slowly lowering the heat you're heating it at so it doesn't have a much hotter core temperature than the surface, and you don't sacrifice anything, because you bring it down in temperature all together and don't introduce new thermal stressors to the piece. It's what people in materials science (including glassworkers and blacksmiths) refer to as annealing, though the specifics differ depending on the exact material being manipulated, obviously. EDIT: I see at the second attempt you remembered this principle and it saved the flask! Bravo.

I think you also lost some water by adding the salt during the heating. Letting the water boil off with a funnel instead of a stopper doesn't help the yield.

Also maybe a tip for next time: Turn down the heat slowly and lets the flask cool slow and steady, rather than just turning the heat off.

Yeah.. salt is kind of hard in rock form. Look at the big slabs of Tibetan pink rock salt they sell. You need a jaw crusher or ball mill or something for that. The thing is though, every time you opened the flask you skewed your results by allowing water vapor to exit the flask as well as ambient humidity to enter it, the same for your recovery vessel being open and not sealed with an one way/check valve vent. Also by exposing the super dry salt to the air it was likely hygroscopic and absorbing latent humidity into itself bonding with the water in the air and adding more water back into the mix again skewing the results. To do it properly you'd have to have it in either a completely humidity controlled area or fully sealed 100% of the way through. A stir stick also might've helped drive off the last of the water.

My first thought on powdering the rock like blocks was to use a ball mill. A smaller one can be made from a rock tumbler and steel balls (I used different size balls together.). I bought a Harbor Freight rock tumbler to make a small one. They can also be made as big as you need it to be, up to weighing tons.

Coordination compounds often expand when they're formed, so you kinda doomed the flask once you overfilled it. Also, you don't really need to grind everything into a powder, once the compound is reheated and loses water it gets looser and crumblier.
BTW this a pain in the ass when dealing with anhydrous salts in a lab. If you let any humidity to break in, it WILL cake and it WILL break the glass. Coordination compounds take far more space than the anhydrous counterparts after all.

It's worth pointing out that "Bath Salts" was not a particular drug, but rather a whole class of drugs. Some folks figured out that they could legally sell analogues of methamphetamine (and a few other new phenethylamines, and even some ketamine derivatives) by labeling them as "bath salts" or other things that were explicitly "not for human consumption". The issue with them was not that they were more dangerous compounds than meth or ketamine, but rather that people didn't know exactly what they were getting, or what dosage to take. The result was people who ended up taking way too much and going into amphetamine psychosis.
I was today years old when I learned that people "high on bath salts" didn't actually consume literal bath salts.

Hey, I posted this in your discord, but this would be an interesting video idea.

Just joined the server(and read rules, so no pinging). I have successfully performed the electrolysis of molten sodium hydroxide to get sodium metal(castner process). I got very small amounts of sodium because I am one of them so called ‘kitchen chemists’ and don’t have the proper equipment to do most experiments. This resulted in the sodium being oxidized quickly and it dissolving back into the melt. However, I had a small metal dish, a power supply with electrodes, and a face shield so I could do it.

This is a chemical Nile uses in almost video. I think this would be a good topic for a NileRed video. Maybe the video could explore other ways of sodium extraction from other sodium salts such as sodium nitrITE. Maybe it could even go as far as experimenting with the down’s process of mixing sodium chloride and calcium chloride and electrolyzing that.

TL;DR Extract sodium from sodium hydroxide and potentially other sodium salts via electrolysis.

In making anhydrous magnesium sulfate for dehydration, I’ve also noticed that it seems to give off some sort of sulfur compound when heated to temperatures much lower than 1000 Celsius. My theory is that when water has been completely driven off, the decomposition reaction is actually an equilibrium between MgO, SO3 and MgSO4, with the equilibrium point depending on temperature. Only a tiny amount of SO3 is ever formed, but because it has such a strong smell and effect on pH, it’s enough to be noticeable. If this is the case, this would actually be a relatively easy way to make dilute sulfuric acid.

NileRed, the by product you produced looks exactly like part of the pulp mill process from a Copeland Fluidized bed reactor.  MgSo3 acid to cook wood chips to make pulp.  The process of washing the pulp produces a "liquor" and is concentrated to a level that can be burned to recover the Mg and SO2 and through a few more processes make MgSO3 again to start the process all over.  There is a lot of chemistry in this product because if the conditions are not right, there are by products of many type produced that are not helpful.

12:10 From experience, I know that it gets hard when you dehydrate it incompletely. Trust me, if you just put it under much more heat, like 500 C maybe, it will turn into a powder on its own. When I used to dehydrate Epsom salt, the powder phase told me that it was completely anhydrous. Also, it's much better if you spread it out over a large surface area. It's harder to dehydrate all bunched up.
